title: Matteo Guendouzi explains his 'rugby tackle' on Wilfried Zaha in Arsenal's draw vs Crystal Palace
text:

Matteo Guendouzi feels it was a case of needs-must in reference to his rugby tackle on Wilfried Zaha on Sunday.

The Gunners youngster hauled Zaha to the turf as he attempted to launch a counter attack in the dying seconds of Arsenal's draw with Crystal Palace .

Zaha had knocked the ball past Guendouzi, who was the last defender, before the Frenchman wiped him out with clear intent.

The tackle set tempers flaring amongst Palace players, but Guendouzi escaped a red card, earning a booking instead.

"I had to foul Zaha at the end, otherwise he is through on goal on his own," said Guendouzi.

(Image: REUTERS)

"I’m the last defender but I’m far from our goal as well. I had to do it."

Two other Gunners players were chasing back, but were behind Zaha at the point of Guendouzi's contact.

Whether he would have made it the 40-odd yards to Arsenal's area without being challenged is unknown, but Palace boss Roy Hodgson was unimpressed with the referee's decision.

"There’s no way he wanted to cause any harm," Hodgson said.

(Image: REUTERS)

"He just wanted to stop Zaha getting free because they wouldn’t have caught him and it would have been a case of can he convert one-on-one.

"I think he is quite lucky he got the yellow card, some might say it was a red, but that’s of no interest to me.

"I’m just disappointed Wilf didn’t get chance to win the game for us."

Arsenal had already let a two-goal lead slip against Palace, while captain Granit Xhaka was booed off by his own fans after being substituted.

(Image: Getty Images)

However Gunners legend Ian Wright called on the Swiss international to apologise to the club's fans after he swore at them on his way off the field before removing his shirt and walking down the tunnel.

"Players getting booed is not the best, but this is the captain," Wright said.

"They are frustrated that he hasn't run off the pitch. I've seen him before bolt off when he's substituted. He's walked off and then he goads them.

"We're talking about fans who have watched him play a handful of good games in three years. And he's treating them like that."
description: The Frenchman halted Zaha's route to goal in injury time of the clash between the sides at the Emirates
